data.question: In what decade was most of the science of project management first created?
data.explanation: The science of project management was first formally created by the U.S. Air Force, U.S. Navy, Dow and Dupont chemical companies during the 1950s.

data.question: What is the average success rate for waterfall projects?
data.explanation: Only about 14% of waterfall projects are deemed successful. 57% are challenged and 29% are deemed failures.

data.question: What is the average success rate for Agile projects?
data.explanation: Agile development has a success rate of 42% with 49% of projects being challenged and 9% failed.

data.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three major development methodologies?
data.explanation:
The three (3) major development methodologies include:
- Waterfall
- Spiral
- Agile

data.question: Which of the following is a problem caused by using a waterfall methodology?
items: Requirements are allowed to flex and adapt to the needs of the stakeholders
Stakeholders are constantly able to see working versions of the product of the project
Stakeholders commonly expect to work with the team on a daily basis to deliver the project results
The process gives the appearance that all the requirements are accurately defined at the beginning of the project with the expectation of little or no changes throughout the project
data.explanation: A key concern with using the waterfall methodology is that it often gives the appearance that all the requirements are accurately defined at the beginning of the project with the accompanying expectation of little or no changes throughout the project.

data.question: Which of the following kinds of projects are best suited to take advantage of Agile development?
data.explanation: Agile development is most effective at managing complicated and/or complex projects.

data.question: Which of the following is a term used to denote an organization's partially finished goods waiting for completion and eventual sales, or the value of these items?
data.explanation: In Agile development it is most commonly called Work in Progress, or WIP, but it can also be called Work in Process or Goods in Process.

data.question: Which of the following core Agile values is not correct?
items: Responding to change over following a plan
data.explanation:
The four core values for Agile development include:
- Individuals & interactions over processes & tools
- Customer collaboration over contract negotiations
- Responding to change over following a plan
- Working software over comprehensive documentation

data.question: What percentage of software features are never used?
data.explanation: 36% of features are truly needed. Another 19% are rarely used, and a full 45% are never used.

data.question: Which of the following is not considered a major founder of Scrum?
data.explanation: Scrum was largely founded by Ken Schwaber and Jeff Sutherland. Early on, Mike Cohn was one of the largest contributors and was a founder of the Scrum Alliance.

data.question: Which of the following is a key theoretical basis of Scrum?
data.explanation: Scrum is based on industrial process theory which is focused on self-organization and emergence. Scrum also makes use of the empirical processes over defined processes but that was not part of the question.

data.question: Which of the following is not a key to empirical process management?
data.explanation:
An empirical process focuses on three key aspects:
- Visibility: you must be able to see it.
- Inspection: you must actually look at it.
- Adaptation: you must change when you see the need.

data.question: Which of the following is not one of the three basic Scrum roles?
data.explanation:
The three roles found in Scrum are:
- The Product Owner
- The Scrum Master
- The Development Team, sometimes just called the Team

data.question: Who is responsible to remove impediments identified by the Development Team, Product Owner or Scrum Master?
data.explanation: All stakeholders are responsible to remove impediments identified by the Development Team, Product Owner or Scrum Master.

data.question: Who is responsible to avoid distracting the Team after the Team has committed to the Sprint Goal?
data.explanation: All stakeholders are responsible to avoid distracting the Team after the Team has committed to the Sprint Goal.

data.question: Who coaches the Development Team in organizational environments in which Scrum is not yet fully adopted and understood?
data.explanation: The Scrum Master coaches the Development Team in organizational environments in which Scrum is not yet fully adopted and understood.

data.question: Which Scrum role observes end to end flow of product delivery and takes action to maximize the delivery of value?
data.explanation: The Scrum Master observes end to end flow of product delivery and takes action to maximize the delivery of value.

data.question: Which Scrum participant changes their mind, substitutes functionality, and adjusts priorities without paying exorbitant costs?
data.explanation: Business Stakeholders change their mind, substitute functionality, and adjust priorities without paying exorbitant costs.

data.question: Which Scrum participant regularly demonstrates a working product at the Sprint Review?
data.explanation: The Scrum Team regularly demonstrates a working product at the Sprint Review.

data.question: Which Scrum participant helps create and maintain the Sprint Backlog, Sprint Burndown Chart and Task Board?
data.explanation: The Development Team helps create and maintain the Sprint Backlog, Sprint Burndown Chart and Task Board.

data.question: Which Scrum participant provides daily status updates to the Scrum Master at the Daily Scrum?
data.explanation: No one provides daily status updates to the Scrum Master at the Daily Scrum. Status updates are provided to and by the Scrum Team.

data.question: Which of the following states work will expand to fill the allotted time?
data.explanation: Parkinson’s Law states, “Work will expand to fill the allotted time.”

data.question: Which of the following says your work will take longer than expected even when you take the Law in account?
data.explanation: Hofstadter’s Law states work will take longer than estimated even when taking into account Hofstadter’s Law.

data.question: Which of the following is not a key element of the Product Backlog?
items: A prioritized list of items to be delivered
Backlog items are relatively independent of the others
Backlog items must always be in the form of User Stories
Backlog items may be reprioritized at any time
data.explanation: The Product Backlog is a prioritized list of items to be delivered. These items are relatively independent of the others and may be reprioritized at any time. However popular User Stories are, it is not a requirement that all requirements be in the form of User Stories.

data.question: Which of the following is the primary tool used by a Scrum Team to track what work is being done on a project through an individual sprint?
data.explanation: A Burndown Chart is the primary tool used by a Scrum Team to track what work is being done on a project through an individual sprint.

data.question: Which of the following is not a key question used to evaluate a Work Breakdown Structure?
items: Can you accurately estimate the resources needed to produce the Work Packages?
Can you estimate how long the Work Packages will take to produce?
Are all Work Packages assigned to specific resources?
If you had to assign the Work Packages to someone else, would they understand exactly what to do?
data.explanation:
The four key questions used to evaluate a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) include:
- Can you accurately estimate the resources needed to produce the Work Packages?
- Can you estimate how long the Work Packages will take to produce?
- If you had to assign the Work Packages to someone else, would they understand exactly what to do?
- If we do these items, and only these items, do we meet the success criteria?

data.question: Which of the four key questions concerning evaluating the WBS is most important?
items: Can you accurately estimate the resources needed to produce the Work Packages?
Can you estimate how long the Work Packages will take to produce?
If you had to assign the Work Packages to someone else, would they understand exactly what to do?
If we do these items, and only these items, do we meet the success criteria?
data.explanation: The most important question concerning WBS's is, 'If we do these items, and only these items, do we meet the success criteria?'

data.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the three (3) key elements of a User Story?
data.explanation:
User Story is made up of three components:
- The Role
- The Action, Result or Need
- The Confirmation or acceptance criteria

data.question: When discussing User Stories, which of the following is not part of making your acceptance criteria SAFE?
data.explanation:
The acronym SAFE is used when discussing User Stories to address proper acceptance criteria. The acronym stands for:
- Success: Achieves desired result
- Advance: Moves closer to success
- Failure: Fail alternative path
- Error: Error exception, outside program control

data.question: Which of the following is not one of the three (3) Cs of user stories?
data.explanation:
Stories are a very powerful tool for defining requirements. They largely work by using the 3 Cs:
Card – The brief description must have meaning to both the team and the product owner.
Conversation – This is the most important part. The card is not enough to write code. The card leads to a conversation to ensure understanding.
Confirmation – This is the success criteria. It gives us the high-level criteria against which the resulting feature will be tested.

data.question: Which of the following is a key strength of using User Stories?
items: User Stories make defining requirements easier
User Stories make requirements understood by all stakeholders
User Stories are more stable and allow requirements to change less frequently
Encourages effective communication about requirements through frequent face-to-face interactions
data.explanation:
The strengths of using User Stories include:
- Encourages effective communication about requirements through frequent face-to-face interactions.
- Avoids too much detail which can increase cost without any benefit [Forrester & Simula].
- Better adaptation to change.
- Acknowledges the fact that all requirements are NOT known at the beginning.

data.question: Which of the following is a key acronym when discussing User Stories?
data.explanation:
INVEST is a key acronym for User Stories. It means:
- Independent: From other stories.
- Negotiable: Not set in stone.
- Valuable: Don’t do it if it’s not necessary.
- Estimatable: You must be able to come up with realistic numbers.
- Small: Size matters!
- Testable: You must be able to prove it works.

data.question: When grooming backlog items, how much time should team members expect to spend on their grooming efforts?
data.explanation: The Scrum Guide and other writing recommends the Product Owner spends the most time grooming the Product Backlog. However, in general it is recommended that 10% of total time be spent on grooming activities.

data.question: How does Scrum respond to the problem most projects face with unfocused project management?
items: Scrum shrinks the number of people involved in projects
Scrum employs Parkinson’s Law to maintain focus
Scrum has teams that are dedicated to one and only one project
data.explanation: A big reason why Scrum works is because it shrinks the size of the project to a group of six plus or minus three. These smaller groups are focused on one and only one project. It is possible to allow Product Owners and Scrum Masters to work on multiple projects.

data.question: How does Scrum respond to the problem most projects face with a focus on task management?
items: Scrum has the Development Team manage deliverables on a daily basis
Scrum makes use of Gantt Charts to manage deliverables
Scrum makes use of Dempster’s Law
data.explanation: Scrum makes use of a daily reporting model when the team reports to each other what was actually completed the previous day along with what they were going to complete that day and any impediments.

data.question: Which of the following is the best definition of the Student Syndrome?
items: The belief that further study is required to determine an estimate
The belief that there is too much time to complete the effort
The belief that there is more than enough time to complete the effort, causing the student to not start until very late in the process
The belief that there is not enough time for the deliverable, so the person starts work early
data.explanation: The Student Syndrome is the belief that there is more than enough time to complete the effort, causing the student to not start until very late in the process.

data.question: Which of the following tools is used to measure the progress of a project within a Sprint?
data.explanation: A Burndown Chart is used by Scrum Teams to measure the progress of the project during a single Sprint.

data.question: Which of the following is not a key question to determine if you are really doing Scrum?
items: Do you have a project sponsor?
Is there a recognized Product Owner?
Is there a Development Team with 3 to 9 members?
data.explanation: Project Sponsors do not exist in a Scrum Project. The Product Owner is responsible for the duties of a Project Sponsor.

data.question: Which of the following is not a key question to determine if you are really doing Scrum?
items: Does the Development Team create a plan each day at a Daily Scrum?
Is the increment inspected by stakeholders at a Sprint Review?
Is the Team using a Cumulative Flow Chart?
Does the Scrum Team conduct a Sprint Retrospective each Sprint?
data.explanation: Cumulative Flow Charts are a part of Scrum, but not all Scrum projects use a Cumulative Flow Chart. The only required chart is a Burndown Chart. Additionally, a Burn-Up is strongly recommended.

data.question: In Alistair Cockburn’s Shu-Ha-Ri, what does the Ha level of knowledge represent?
items: Breakaway from the process & make it your own
Detach from the process and break some of the rules
data.explanation:
Cockburn’s Shu-Ha-Ri contains three levels:
Shu – Level 1: Follow the rules.
Ha – Level 2: Detach from process. Break the rule.
Ri – Level 3: Breakaway from process & make your own. Be the rule.
